biogHist.abstract: Henrietta Greville established her life-long involvement with the labour movement when she moved to the goldfields at West Wyalong, following the breakdown of her marriage to John Collins. Here she pegged out a claim, sold meals to the miners and helped establish a branch of the Political Labor League, as well as meeting her future husband, miner and union organizer, Hector Greville. To help support her family Greville, at times, worked as a seamstress. Later she became an organizer for the Australian Workers' Union, the Women Workers' Union, and for some time acted as its delegate at the Trades and Labor Council. As a Labor candidate, Greville was defeated for the federal seat of Wentworth in 1917 and the state seat of Vaucluse in 1927. Greville became associated with the Workers' Educational Association of New South Wales in 1914 when she joined an economics class. By 1918 she was branch secretary at Lithgow, became a member of the executive in 1919 and the first woman president in 1920. Greville was still active with the association in 1954, at the age of 94. On 1 January 1958 Henrietta Greville was appointed a Member of the Order of the British Empire for social welfare services in New South Wales.

chronItem.event: Moved with her parents Henry and Rebecca (n√©e Hutchinson) Wyse and siblings from New Zealand to Victoria
Married John Collins a jeweller at Albury Registry Office
Delegate to Trades and Labor Council
Organiser for the Australian Workers Union
Married Hector Greville a miner and union organizer
Organizer for the White Workers' Union and attacked the working conditions and wages of female shirt-makers
Joined the first tutorial class of the Workers' Educational Association (WEA) of New South Wales and studied economics for two years
Stood, unsuccessfully, for the Federal electorate seat of Wentworth, representing the Women's Central Organising Committee of the Australian Labor Party
First woman to be elected president of WEA
Labor candidate for the New South Wales State seat of Vaucluse
President of the Labor Women's Advisory Council
Worked for the Rockdale branch of the Original Old Age and Invalid Pensioners' Association
Became a life-member of the Union of Australian Women
Aged 94 directed a group of women studing sex hygiene for WEA
Appointed Member of the Order of the British Empire for social welfare services in New South Wales

resourceRelation.relationEntry: Edited Book: Australian Feminism: A Companion
William Morrow - recordings of addresses given by Jessie Street, and interviews with Jessie Street, 1953-1960

archref.repository: Mitchell Library and Sir William Dixson Research Library, State Library of New South Wales
archref.unittitle: William Morrow - recordings of addresses given by Jessie Street, and interviews with Jessie Street, 1953-1960
archref.abstract: Sound recordings - 7hrs 40mins. 1953; Recording of the 50th anniversary celebration of women's suffrage in Australia, including a welcome to delegates, speakers include Dame Mary Gilmore and Henrietta Greville, 16 December 1953. (Locn No.: CY MLOH 52/1) n.d.; Recording of Jessie Street in conversation on nuclear disarmament (Locn No.: CY MLOH 52/2) 1960; Recording of Dr Linus Pauling and Mrs Pauling speaking at St Pancras Town Hall, England, on why the world must disarm, 17 July 1960 (Locn No.: CY MLOH 52/3) 1959; Recording of the Deserted Wives Conference, speakers include Jessie Street (Locn No.: CY MLOH 52/4-5) n.d.; Recording of Jessie Street speaking on aspects of China; and a recording of a news item in which Jessie Street comments on allegations that the Conference on Disarmament was a communist initiative. (Locn No.: CY MLOH 52/6) n.d.; 'A World without War', being a recording of the British Peace Party National Conference on Disarmament (Locn No.: CY MLOH 52/7) n.d.; Interviews by Jessie Street with suffragettes including Lilian Lenton, Charlotte Marsh, Eileen Casey and Mary Leigh. They recall being in prison, confrontations with the police, and hunger strikes. (Locn No.: CY MLOH 52/8) n.d.; 'Women of Britain. The Story of their Struggle', by Nancy Brush, read by Pat Burke; and interviews by Jessie Street with Charlotte Marsh, Eileen Casey and Mary Leigh (Locn No.: CY MLOH 52/9) n.d.; Recording of Jessie Street speaking about China including illiteracy, living conditions and nomadic minority races (Locn No.: CY MLOH 52/10-12)
